Location

Westminster

About the job

Job summary

We are looking for a Head of Policy Research in our Committee Office at the House of Lords. This is a brand-new position where you’ll be able to get hands on to set the standards and help develop policy research for Lords Committees! 

This is an exciting opportunity for someone who wants to make a real difference in helping Lords Select Committees to improve and examine public policy and scrutinise legislation!

Job description

You’ll be accountable for –

  • Overseeing and developing the quality of policy research, analysis, and advice provided to House of Lords select committees
  • Providing professional leadership on policy analysis
  • Supporting innovation and spreading best practice
  • Developing and maintaining connections with policy analysis professionals across Parliament
  • Providing leadership to the whole Committee Office as part of the senior management team

If this sounds like something you would like to hear more about, please apply below

What we’re looking for –

  • Expertise in undertaking high quality analysis on public policy matters
  • Ability to provide professional leadership, setting priorities and delivering on them
  • Excellent written and oral communication skills

It would be even better if you had or if you’re willing to learn…

  • Understanding of the role and work of select committees

The job description provides full details about the role and what we are looking for.

What you’ll get in return

  • 30 days annual leave (increasing to 35 after one years’ service)
  • Generous pension scheme
  • Discounts from well-known brands and retailers
  • Parliamentary health and wellbeing programme
  • The opportunity to witness history in the making!

The work we do is vital to House of Lords, and you will be a pivotal member in the team strengthening the work of the House. The House of Lords is the second chamber of the UK parliament. It is independent from and complements the work of the House of Commons to:

  • Make laws
  • Check and challenge the actions of the government through questions and debates
  • Investigate public policy and provide a forum of independent expertise

Please complete your online application by 22:00 on Sunday the 2nd of July 2023

If you require any reasonable adjustments during the application process, please contact HLRecruitment@parliament.uk

Job offers are standardly offered at the minimum of the salary range

The House of Lords Administration is committed to increasing diversity and maintaining an inclusive workplace culture. We welcome applications from all candidates regardless of their age, caring responsibilities, disability, gender/sex, gender reassignment/trans status, marriage and civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sexual orientation and socio-economic status. The Administration will also consider flexible working arrangements and reasonable adjustments.

We welcome and encourage job applications from people of all backgrounds. For this role we particularly welcome applications from groups which are currently underrepresented within the team, including applications from Black, Asian and ethnic minority candidates and candidates with disabilities.

Person specification

Leadership and teamwork:

  • The ability to provide professional leadership (as distinct from line management) for the Committee Office’s policy analysis staff.
  • The ability to provide leadership for the whole Committee Office, as part of the senior management team, demonstrating the House’s values of respect, inclusivity, professionalism and responsibility.

Working relationships:

  • The ability to build constructive and supportive working relationships across a range of teams and stakeholders, and with Chairs and Members of select committees. 

Planning and delivery:

  • The ability to oversee and develop the Committee Office’s delivery of policy analysis work, developing appropriate objectives, methodologies and standards for that work.
  • The ability to set and deliver appropriate priorities in this new role.
  • The flexibility and resilience to produce high-quality work to tight and competing deadlines, including as part of a team.

Expertise and judgement:

  • Significant experience of and expertise in undertaking high quality analysis on public policy matters.
  • Good knowledge of the UK public policy environment, and the ability to become proficient in new topics

 Communication:

  • Excellent written and oral communication skills, including the ability to distil large and complex sets of evidence into clear, concise and persuasive written and oral briefings.

Benefits

Details of our employee benefits can be found at https://www.parliament.uk/mps-lords-and-offices/offices/lords/lordshro/employee-benefits/

Things you need to know

Selection process details

Please complete your online application by 10.00pm on Sunday 2 July 2023.

Feedback will only be provided if you attend an interview or assessment.

Security

Successful candidates must undergo a criminal record check.
Successful candidates must meet the security requirements before they can be appointed. The level of security needed is counter-terrorist check (opens in a new window).

See our vetting charter (opens in a new window).
People working with government assets must complete baseline personnel security standard (opens in new window) checks.

Nationality requirements

This job is broadly open to the following groups:

  • UK nationals
  • nationals of Commonwealth countries who have the right to work in the UK
  • nationals of the Republic of Ireland
  • nationals from the EU, EEA or Switzerland with settled or pre-settled status or who apply for either status by the deadline of the European Union Settlement Scheme (EUSS) (opens in a new window)
  • relevant EU, EEA, Swiss or Turkish nationals working in the Civil Service
  • relevant EU, EEA, Swiss or Turkish nationals who have built up the right to work in the Civil Service
  • certain family members of the relevant EU, EEA, Swiss or Turkish nationals
Further information on nationality requirements (opens in a new window)

Working for the Civil Service

The Civil Service Code (opens in a new window) sets out the standards of behaviour expected of civil servants.

We recruit by merit on the basis of fair and open competition, as outlined in the Civil Service Commission's recruitment principles (opens in a new window).
The Civil Service embraces diversity and promotes equal opportunities. As such, we run a Disability Confident Scheme (DCS) for candidates with disabilities who meet the minimum selection criteria.
